005package edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics;
006
007import edu.wpi.first.math.MathSharedStore;
008import edu.wpi.first.math.MathUsageId;
009import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
010import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation2d;
011import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Twist2d;
012import java.util.Arrays;
013import java.util.Collections;
014import org.ejml.simple.SimpleMatrix;
015
016/**
017 * Helper class that converts a chassis velocity (dx, dy, and dtheta components) into individual
018 * module states (speed and angle).
019 *
020 * <p>The inverse kinematics (converting from a desired chassis velocity to individual module
021 * states) uses the relative locations of the modules with respect to the center of rotation. The
022 * center of rotation for inverse kinematics is also variable. This means that you can set your set
023 * your center of rotation in a corner of the robot to perform special evasion maneuvers.
024 *
025 * <p>Forward kinematics (converting an array of module states into the overall chassis motion) is
026 * performs the exact opposite of what inverse kinematics does. Since this is an overdetermined
027 * system (more equations than variables), we use a least-squares approximation.
028 *
029 * <p>The inverse kinematics: [moduleStates] = [moduleLocations] * [chassisSpeeds] We take the
030 * Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of [moduleLocations] and then multiply by [moduleStates] to get our
031 * chassis speeds.
032 *
033 * <p>Forward kinematics is also used for odometry -- determining the position of the robot on the
034 * field using encoders and a gyro.
035 */
036public class SwerveDriveKinematics {
037  private final SimpleMatrix m_inverseKinematics;
038  private final SimpleMatrix m_forwardKinematics;
039
040  private final int m_numModules;
041  private final Translation2d[] m_modules;
042  private final SwerveModuleState[] m_moduleStates;
043  private Translation2d m_prevCoR = new Translation2d();
044
045  /**
046   * Constructs a swerve drive kinematics object. This takes in a variable number of wheel locations
047   * as Translation2ds. The order in which you pass in the wheel locations is the same order that
048   * you will receive the module states when performing inverse kinematics. It is also expected that
049   * you pass in the module states in the same order when calling the forward kinematics methods.
050   *
051   * @param wheelsMeters The locations of the wheels relative to the physical center of the robot.
052   */
053  public SwerveDriveKinematics(Translation2d... wheelsMeters) {
054    if (wheelsMeters.length < 2) {
055      throw new IllegalArgumentException("A swerve drive requires at least two modules");
056    }
057    m_numModules = wheelsMeters.length;
058    m_modules = Arrays.copyOf(wheelsMeters, m_numModules);
059    m_moduleStates = new SwerveModuleState[m_numModules];
060    Arrays.fill(m_moduleStates, new SwerveModuleState());
061    m_inverseKinematics = new SimpleMatrix(m_numModules * 2, 3);
062
063    for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
064      m_inverseKinematics.setRow(i * 2 + 0, 0, /* Start Data */ 1, 0, -m_modules[i].getY());
065      m_inverseKinematics.setRow(i * 2 + 1, 0, /* Start Data */ 0, 1, +m_modules[i].getX());
066    }
067    m_forwardKinematics = m_inverseKinematics.pseudoInverse();
068
069    MathSharedStore.reportUsage(MathUsageId.kKinematics_SwerveDrive, 1);
070  }
071
072  /**
073   * Performs inverse kinematics to return the module states from a desired chassis velocity. This
074   * method is often used to convert joystick values into module speeds and angles.
075   *
076   * <p>This function also supports variable centers of rotation. During normal operations, the
077   * center of rotation is usually the same as the physical center of the robot; therefore, the
078   * argument is defaulted to that use case. However, if you wish to change the center of rotation
079   * for evasive maneuvers, vision alignment, or for any other use case, you can do so.
080   *
081   * <p>In the case that the desired chassis speeds are zero (i.e. the robot will be stationary),
082   * the previously calculated module angle will be maintained.
083   *
084   * @param chassisSpeeds The desired chassis speed.
085   * @param centerOfRotationMeters The center of rotation. For example, if you set the center of
086   *     rotation at one corner of the robot and provide a chassis speed that only has a dtheta
087   *     component, the robot will rotate around that corner.
088   * @return An array containing the module states. Use caution because these module states are not
089   *     normalized. Sometimes, a user input may cause one of the module speeds to go above the
090   *     attainable max velocity. Use the {@link #desaturateWheelSpeeds(SwerveModuleState[], double)
091   *     DesaturateWheelSpeeds} function to rectify this issue.
092   */
093  @SuppressWarnings("PMD.MethodReturnsInternalArray")
094  public SwerveModuleState[] toSwerveModuleStates(
095      ChassisSpeeds chassisSpeeds, Translation2d centerOfRotationMeters) {
096    if (chassisSpeeds.vxMetersPerSecond == 0.0
097        && chassisSpeeds.vyMetersPerSecond == 0.0
098        && chassisSpeeds.omegaRadiansPerSecond == 0.0) {
099      for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
100        m_moduleStates[i].speedMetersPerSecond = 0.0;
101      }
102
103      return m_moduleStates;
104    }
105
106    if (!centerOfRotationMeters.equals(m_prevCoR)) {
107      for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
108        m_inverseKinematics.setRow(
109            i * 2 + 0,
110            0, /* Start Data */
111            1,
112            0,
113            -m_modules[i].getY() + centerOfRotationMeters.getY());
114        m_inverseKinematics.setRow(
115            i * 2 + 1,
116            0, /* Start Data */
117            0,
118            1,
119            +m_modules[i].getX() - centerOfRotationMeters.getX());
120      }
121      m_prevCoR = centerOfRotationMeters;
122    }
123
124    var chassisSpeedsVector = new SimpleMatrix(3, 1);
125    chassisSpeedsVector.setColumn(
126        0,
127        0,
128        chassisSpeeds.vxMetersPerSecond,
129        chassisSpeeds.vyMetersPerSecond,
130        chassisSpeeds.omegaRadiansPerSecond);
131
132    var moduleStatesMatrix = m_inverseKinematics.mult(chassisSpeedsVector);
133
134    for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
135      double x = moduleStatesMatrix.get(i * 2, 0);
136      double y = moduleStatesMatrix.get(i * 2 + 1, 0);
137
138      double speed = Math.hypot(x, y);
139      Rotation2d angle = new Rotation2d(x, y);
140
141      m_moduleStates[i] = new SwerveModuleState(speed, angle);
142    }
143
144    return m_moduleStates;
145  }
146
147  /**
148   * Performs inverse kinematics. See {@link #toSwerveModuleStates(ChassisSpeeds, Translation2d)}
149   * toSwerveModuleStates for more information.
150   *
151   * @param chassisSpeeds The desired chassis speed.
152   * @return An array containing the module states.
153   */
154  public SwerveModuleState[] toSwerveModuleStates(ChassisSpeeds chassisSpeeds) {
155    return toSwerveModuleStates(chassisSpeeds, new Translation2d());
156  }
157
158  /**
159   * Performs forward kinematics to return the resulting chassis state from the given module states.
160   * This method is often used for odometry -- determining the robot's position on the field using
161   * data from the real-world speed and angle of each module on the robot.
162   *
163   * @param wheelStates The state of the modules (as a SwerveModuleState type) as measured from
164   *     respective encoders and gyros. The order of the swerve module states should be same as
165   *     passed into the constructor of this class.
166   * @return The resulting chassis speed.
167   */
168  public ChassisSpeeds toChassisSpeeds(SwerveModuleState... wheelStates) {
169    if (wheelStates.length != m_numModules) {
170      throw new IllegalArgumentException(
171          "Number of modules is not consistent with number of wheel locations provided in "
172              + "constructor");
173    }
174    var moduleStatesMatrix = new SimpleMatrix(m_numModules * 2, 1);
175
176    for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
177      var module = wheelStates[i];
178      moduleStatesMatrix.set(i * 2, 0, module.speedMetersPerSecond * module.angle.getCos());
179      moduleStatesMatrix.set(i * 2 + 1, module.speedMetersPerSecond * module.angle.getSin());
180    }
181
182    var chassisSpeedsVector = m_forwardKinematics.mult(moduleStatesMatrix);
183    return new ChassisSpeeds(
184        chassisSpeedsVector.get(0, 0),
185        chassisSpeedsVector.get(1, 0),
186        chassisSpeedsVector.get(2, 0));
187  }
188
189  /**
190   * Performs forward kinematics to return the resulting chassis state from the given module states.
191   * This method is often used for odometry -- determining the robot's position on the field using
192   * data from the real-world speed and angle of each module on the robot.
193   *
194   * @param wheelDeltas The latest change in position of the modules (as a SwerveModulePosition
195   *     type) as measured from respective encoders and gyros. The order of the swerve module states
196   *     should be same as passed into the constructor of this class.
197   * @return The resulting Twist2d.
198   */
199  public Twist2d toTwist2d(SwerveModulePosition... wheelDeltas) {
200    if (wheelDeltas.length != m_numModules) {
201      throw new IllegalArgumentException(
202          "Number of modules is not consistent with number of wheel locations provided in "
203              + "constructor");
204    }
205    var moduleDeltaMatrix = new SimpleMatrix(m_numModules * 2, 1);
206
207    for (int i = 0; i < m_numModules; i++) {
208      var module = wheelDeltas[i];
209      moduleDeltaMatrix.set(i * 2, 0, module.distanceMeters * module.angle.getCos());
210      moduleDeltaMatrix.set(i * 2 + 1, module.distanceMeters * module.angle.getSin());
211    }
212
213    var chassisDeltaVector = m_forwardKinematics.mult(moduleDeltaMatrix);
214    return new Twist2d(
215        chassisDeltaVector.get(0, 0), chassisDeltaVector.get(1, 0), chassisDeltaVector.get(2, 0));
216  }
217
218  /**
219   * Renormalizes the wheel speeds if any individual speed is above the specified maximum.
220   *
221   * <p>Sometimes, after inverse kinematics, the requested speed from one or more modules may be
222   * above the max attainable speed for the driving motor on that module. To fix this issue, one can
223   * reduce all the wheel speeds to make sure that all requested module speeds are at-or-below the
224   * absolute threshold, while maintaining the ratio of speeds between modules.
225   *
226   * @param moduleStates Reference to array of module states. The array will be mutated with the
227   *     normalized speeds!
228   * @param attainableMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond The absolute max speed that a module can reach.
229   */
230  public static void desaturateWheelSpeeds(
231      SwerveModuleState[] moduleStates, double attainableMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond) {
232    double realMaxSpeed = Collections.max(Arrays.asList(moduleStates)).speedMetersPerSecond;
233    if (realMaxSpeed > attainableMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond) {
234      for (SwerveModuleState moduleState : moduleStates) {
235        moduleState.speedMetersPerSecond =
236            moduleState.speedMetersPerSecond / realMaxSpeed * attainableMaxSpeedMetersPerSecond;
237      }
238    }
239  }
240
241  /**
242   * Renormalizes the wheel speeds if any individual speed is above the specified maximum, as well
243   * as getting rid of joystick saturation at edges of joystick.
244   *
245   * <p>Sometimes, after inverse kinematics, the requested speed from one or more modules may be
246   * above the max attainable speed for the driving motor on that module. To fix this issue, one can
247   * reduce all the wheel speeds to make sure that all requested module speeds are at-or-below the
248   * absolute threshold, while maintaining the ratio of speeds between modules.
249   *
250   * @param moduleStates Reference to array of module states. The array will be mutated with the
251   *     normalized speeds!
252   * @param currentChassisSpeed The current speed of the robot
253   * @param attainableMaxModuleSpeedMetersPerSecond The absolute max speed that a module can reach
254   * @param attainableMaxTranslationalSpeedMetersPerSecond The absolute max speed that your robot
255   *     can reach while translating
256   * @param attainableMaxRotationalVelocityRadiansPerSecond The absolute max speed the robot can
257   *     reach while rotating
258   */
259  public static void desaturateWheelSpeeds(
260      SwerveModuleState[] moduleStates,
261      ChassisSpeeds currentChassisSpeed,
262      double attainableMaxModuleSpeedMetersPerSecond,
263      double attainableMaxTranslationalSpeedMetersPerSecond,
264      double attainableMaxRotationalVelocityRadiansPerSecond) {
265    double realMaxSpeed = Collections.max(Arrays.asList(moduleStates)).speedMetersPerSecond;
266
267    if (attainableMaxTranslationalSpeedMetersPerSecond == 0
268        || attainableMaxRotationalVelocityRadiansPerSecond == 0
269        || realMaxSpeed == 0) {
270      return;
271    }
272    double translationalK =
273        Math.hypot(currentChassisSpeed.vxMetersPerSecond, currentChassisSpeed.vyMetersPerSecond)
274            / attainableMaxTranslationalSpeedMetersPerSecond;
275    double rotationalK =
276        Math.abs(currentChassisSpeed.omegaRadiansPerSecond)
277            / attainableMaxRotationalVelocityRadiansPerSecond;
278    double k = Math.max(translationalK, rotationalK);
279    double scale = Math.min(k * attainableMaxModuleSpeedMetersPerSecond / realMaxSpeed, 1);
280    for (SwerveModuleState moduleState : moduleStates) {
281      moduleState.speedMetersPerSecond *= scale;
282    }
283  }
284}
